case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 25 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 26, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 235 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 25 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 26, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 235 of 1957.

facts.text: The appeal is directed against the judgment and order of a division Bench of the Allahabad High Court confirming those of a single Judge dismissing the application filed by the appellant to review the order of the High Court dated November 22, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment and order of a division Bench of the Allahabad High Court companyfirming those of a single Judge of that companyrt dismissing the application filed by the appellant to review the order of the High Court dated November 22, 1958.

facts.text: The respondent held certain zamindari and agricultural properties in different districts of the State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading up to the filing of this appeal may be briefly stated. The respondent held certain zamindari and agricultural properties in different districts of the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: On December 22, 1952, the Additional Collector, Banaras, assessed the respondent to an agricultural income-tax of Rs. 99,964-12-0 for the year 1359 fasli under the U. P. Agricultural Income-Tax Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On December 22, 1952, the Additional Collector, Banaras, in exercise of the powers companyferred on him under the provisions of the U. P. Agricultural Income- Tax Act  Act III of 1949 , assessed the respondent to an agricultural income-tax of Rs. 99,964-12-0 for the year 1359 fasli.

facts.text: On September 30, 1955, the respondent filed a petition before the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the assessment order on the ground that the Additional Collector, Banaras, had no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1955, the respondent filed a petition before the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the said order on the ground that the Additional Collector, Banaras, had numberjurisdiction to make the said assessment.

facts.text: On November 22, 1955, Mehrotra J. allowed the writ petition and quashed the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On November 22, 1955, Mehrotra J., allowed the writ petition quashing the said assessment.

facts.text: The State of Uttar Pradesh did not prefer an appeal against the order quashing the assessment and allowed it to become final.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh did number prefer an appeal against the said order and allowed it to become final.

facts.text: On February 9, 1956, the State of Uttar Pradesh promulgated Ordinance No. 11 of 1956, which was subsequently replaced by U. P. Act No. XIV of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On February 9, 1956, the State of Uttar Pradesh promulgated an Ordinance, being Ordinance No. 11 of 1956, which was subsequently replaced by U. P. Act No. XIV of 1956,

facts.text: The Ordinance retrospectively validated assessments made by the Additional Collector and under s.6 conferred a right to apply for review within 90 days.

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of the Ordinance, the assessments made by the Additional Collector were retrospectively validated and, under s.6 thereof, a right was companyferred upon any party to the proceedings under the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948, ... to apply within 90 days...

facts.text: On March 14, 1956, the appellants filed an application in the High Court at Allahabad for review of its order dated November 22, 1955 pursuant to s.6 of the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the provisions of s.6 of the said Ordinance, on March 14, 1956, the appellants filed an application in the High Court at Allahabad for review of its order dated November 22, 1956.

facts.text: Mehrotra J. held that s.11 of the Act did not entitle the appellant to file a review application and dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: The said application was heard, in the first instance, by Mehrotra, J.,. and he held that s. II of the Act, which companyresponds to s.6 of the Ordinance, did number entitle the appellant to file an application for review of an order made by the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants preferred an appeal to a division Bench of the High Court consisting of Nootham C.J. and Srivastava J.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants preferred an appeal against the said order to a division Bench of that companyrt. Nootham, C.J., and Srivastava, J., who heard the appeal,

facts.text: The division Bench dismissed the appeal on two grounds: (1) order refusing review is not a judgment under Ch. VIII r.5; (2) on merits, s.11 does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: Nootham, C.J., and Srivastava, J., who heard the appeal, dismissed it on two grounds, namely,  1  under Ch. VIII r.5 of the Rules of Court, a special appeal against an order of a single Judge of the companyrt can be maintained only if that order amounts to a Judgment,...

facts.text: The present appeal was preferred against the division Bench order.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal, as already stated, was preferred against the said order.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 26, 1962 by Subba Rao J., with Mudholkar J. delivering separate judgment.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 26. The Judgment of Sinha, C.J., Subba Rao and Ayyangar, JJ. was delivered by Subba Rao, J., Mudholkar, J., delivered separate Judgment.

facts.text: Section 2 of U.P. Act XIV of 1956 substituted clause (4) in Section 2 of the Principal Act to include Additional Collector.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2. In Section 2 of the U. P. Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1948  hereinafter called the Principal Act , for clause  4 , the following shall be and be deemed always to have been substituted-  4-a  Collector shall have the meaning as in the U, P. Land Revenue Act, 1901, and will include an Additional Collector appointed under the said Act.

facts.text: Section 10 of the Act validated all orders, actions or proceedings by Additional Collectors prior to amendment.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10. Validation- 1  For the removal of doubts it is hereby declared that-  a  in rule 18 of the, U. P. Agricultural Income Tax Rules, 1949, the expression Collector and Assistant Collector... all orders, actions or proceedings taken... shall be deemed to be as good and valid in law...

facts.text: Section 11 allowed any party to proceedings under Principal Act where assessment set aside for lack of jurisdiction to apply for review within 90 days.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 Review of Proceedings -Where before the companymencement of this Act any companyrt or authority had, in any proceedings under the Principal Act, set aside any assessment made by an Additional Collector... any party to the proceedings may, at any time within ninety days... apply to the Court or authority for a view of the proceedings...

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the order of Mehrotra J. dismissing the review application is a judgment within cl.10 Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, hold that the order of Mehrotra, J., dismissing the application, filed for review of his earlier order, on the ground that s. 11 of the Act did number companyfer any such right on the appellants was a judgment within the meaning of cl.10 of the Letters Patent...

facts.text: Supreme Court held that s.11 does not apply to orders made by High Court under Art.226 as it is not a proceeding under the Principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, we have numberhesitation in holding that, on a plain reading of the clear words used in the section, it does number apply to an order made by the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the order of the High Court is companyrect. The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter VIII r.5 of the Rules of Court provides for an appeal against an order of a single judge. Under that rule a special appeal against an order of a single judge of the court can be maintained only if that order amounts to a judgement. That rule gives effect to cl. 10 of the letters Patent...

issues.text: The order of Mehrotra, J., dismissing the application for review of his earlier order is a Judgment within the meaning of Ch. VIII r. 5 of the Rules of Court and, therefore, an appeal lies against that order to a division Bench of that court.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. C. B. VIII r. 5 of the Rules of Court and, therefore, an appeal lies against that order to a division Bench of that court.

holdings.text: The High Court in exercise of its power under Art. 226 of the Constitution exercises original jurisdiction, though extraordinary.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear from the nature of the power conferred under Art. 226 of the Constitution and the decisions on the subject that the High Court in exercise of its power under Art. 226 of the Constitution exercises original jurisdiction, though the said jurisdiction shall not be confused with the ordinary civil jurisdiction of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents from Madras, Calcutta, Andhra HCs; not appellate/revisional; distinct from continuation of tax proceedings.

holdings.text: We should not give such a construction to the section as would bring it into conflict with Art. 226 of the Constitution and which would have the effect of invalidating it to that extent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second part of s.11 mandates specific orders, derogating HC discretion under Art.226; construe narrowly to save validity.

holdings.text: The order of the High Court is correct. The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The first question, therefore, is whether the order of Mehrotra, J., in an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution was in any proceeding under the Principal Act. Obviously a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution cannot be a proceeding under the Act it is a proceeding under the Constitution.
In the result we hold that the order of the High Court is companyrect. The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

It is, therefore, clear from the nature of the power conferred under Art. 226 of the Constitution and the decisions on the subject that the High Court in exercise of its power under Art. 226 of the Constitution exercises original jurisdiction, though the said jurisdiction shall not be confused with the ordinary civil jurisdiction of the High Court.
In the result we hold that the order of the High Court is companyrect. The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
